The '''Pannonian Basin''' or '''Carpathian Basin'''<ref>{{cite book |last= Eldridge M. Moores, Rhodes Whitmore Fairbridge |first= |coauthors= |title= Encyclopedia of European and Asian Regional Geology|publisher= Springer |year=1997 |month= |isbn= 0412740400, 9780412740404 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Adami Jordan, Peter Jordan, Milan OroÅ¾en AdamiÄ |first= |coauthors=|title= Exonyms and the International Standardisation of Geographical Names: Approaches Towards the Resolution of an Apparent Contradiction|publisher= LIT Verlag Berlin-Hamburg-MÃ¼nster |year= 2007 |month=|pages=240|isbn= 3825800350, 9783825800352 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= George Walter Hoffman, Christopher Shane Davies |first= |coauthors=|title= A Geography of Europe: Problems and Prospects|publisher= Wiley |year= 1983 |month=|pages=647|isbn= 0471897086, 9780471897088 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= George Walter Hoffman, Nels August Bengtson |first= |coauthors=|title= A Geography of Europe|publisher= Ronald Press Co. |year= 1953 |month=|pages=757|isbn=}}</ref> is a large [[sedimentary basin]] in [[East-Central Europe]].
+
The '''Pannonian Basin''' or '''Carpathian Basin'''<ref>{{cite book |last= Eldridge M. Moores, Rhodes Whitmore Fairbridge |first= |coauthors= |title= Encyclopedia of European and Asian Regional Geology|publisher= Springer |year=1997 |month= |isbn= 0412740400, 9780412740404 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Adami Jordan, Peter Jordan, Milan OroÅ¾en AdamiÄ |first= |coauthors=|title= Exonyms and the International Standardisation of Geographical Names: Approaches Towards the Resolution of an Apparent Contradiction|publisher= LIT Verlag Berlin-Hamburg-MÃ¼nster |year= 2007 |month=|pages=240|isbn= 3825800350, 9783825800352 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= George Walter Hoffman, Christopher Shane Davies |first= |coauthors=|title= A Geography of Europe: Problems and Prospects|publisher= Wiley |year= 1983 |month=|pages=647|isbn= 0471897086, 9780471897088 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= George Walter Hoffman, Nels August Bengtson |first= |coauthors=|title= A Geography of Europe|publisher= Ronald Press Co. |year= 1953 |month=|pages=757|isbn=}}</ref> is a large [[Sedimentary basin|basin]] in [[East-Central Europe]].
The [[Geomorphology|geomorphological]] term '''Pannonian Plain''' is more widely{{dubious|date=September 2011}} used for roughly the same region though with a somewhat different sense{{dubious|date=September 2011}} - meaning only the lowlands, the [[plain]] that remained when the [[Pliocene]] ''[[Pannonian Sea]]'' dried out.
The [[Geomorphology|geomorphological]] term '''Pannonian Plain''' is more widely{{dubious|date=September 2011}} used for roughly the same region though with a somewhat different sense{{dubious|date=September 2011}} - meaning only the lowlands, the [[plain]] that remained when the [[Pliocene]] ''[[Pannonian Sea]]'' dried out.
It is a geomorphological subsystem of the [[Alpide belt|Alps-Himalaya system]]. The river [[Danube]] divides the plain roughly in half.
It is a geomorphological subsystem of the [[Alpide belt|Alps-Himalaya system]]. The river [[Danube]] divides the plain roughly in half.
Line 20: Line 20:
In English, the terms "Pannonian Basin" and "Carpathian Basin" are used synonymously.
In English, the terms "Pannonian Basin" and "Carpathian Basin" are used synonymously.
The name "Pannonian" is taken from that of [[Pannonia province|Pannonia]], a province of the [[Roman Empire]]. The historical province overlapped but was not coterminous with the geographical plain or basin.<ref>[[Pannonia Inferior]] covered much of the western half of the basin, as far as the [[Danube]]. [[Pannonia Superior]] included the western fringe of the basn as well as part of the [[Eastern Alps]], as far as [[Virunum]]. The southern fringe of the basin was in [[Dalmatia (Roman province)|Dalmatia]] and [[Moesia]]. The eastern half of the basin was not conquered by the Romans, and was considered part of [[Sarmatia]], inhabited by the [[Iazyges]]. Likewise, the parts north of the Danube (now in western Slovakia) were not in the empire; they were considered part of [[Germania]], inhabited by the [[Quadi]].</ref>
The name "Pannonian" is taken from that of [[Pannonia province|Pannonia]], a province of the [[Roman Empire]]. The historical province overlapped but was not coterminous with the geographical plain or basin.<ref>[[Pannonia Inferior]] covered much of the western half of the basin, as far as the [[Danube]]. [[Pannonia Superior]] included the western fringe of the basn as well as part of the [[Eastern Alps]], as far as [[Virunum]]. The southern fringe of the basin was in [[Dalmatia (Roman province)|Dalmatia]] and [[Moesia]]. The eastern half of the basin was not conquered by the Romans, and was considered part of [[Sarmatia]], inhabited by the [[Iazyges]]. Likewise, the parts north of the Danube (now in western Slovakia) were not in the empire; they were considered part of [[Germania]], inhabited by the [[Quadi]].</ref>
â
The term ''Pannonian Plain'' is used in most sources, which refers to the lowland parts of the Pannonian Basin as well as those of some adjoining regions like [[Lower Austria]], [[Moravia]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]]. The lands adjoining the plain proper are sometimes also called ''peri-Pannonian''.
+
In the English language ''Pannonian Basin'' or ''Carpathian Basin'' are generally not used as geographical terms.{{cn|date=September 2011}} Instead, the term ''Pannonian Plain'' is used in most sources, which refers to the lowland parts of the Pannonian Basin as well as those of some adjoining regions like [[Lower Austria]], [[Moravia]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina|Bosnia]]. The lands adjoining the plain proper are sometimes also called ''peri-Pannonian''.
The term ''Carpathian Basin'' is used in [[Hungary|Hungarian]] literature, while the [[South Slavic languages]], [[Slovak language|Slovak]], [[Romanian language|Romanian]] and [[German language|German]] use ''Pannonian'':
The term ''Carpathian Basin'' is used in [[Hungary|Hungarian]] literature, while the [[South Slavic languages]], [[Slovak language|Slovak]], [[Romanian language|Romanian]] and [[German language|German]] use ''Pannonian'':
